fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as Set functors are monads.

This characterisation is useful for enumerating all possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.

I am a PhD student at Royal Holloway, University of London researching programming language semantics via cyclic proof theory, type theory, and category theory.
276mhe-0001mhe-0001.xml\mu HOL^{ex}20241113Chris Purdy
\mu HOL^{ex} is a proof system that I've been developing for part of my PhD project with my supervisor Reuben Rowe.
The goal is to develop a proof system for higher-order logic with fixed-point operators, that allows for induction and coinduction by adding fixed-point "unfolding" rules, and allowing proofs to be cyclic. 278lsd-0001lsd-0001.xmlDistributive laws of monad containers20241113Chris Purdy
Joint work with Stefania Damato on characterising distributive laws between monad containers. Monad containers were originally characterised by Tarmo Uustalu - these are containers with extra structure such that their interpretation as Set functors are monads.
This characterisation is useful for enumerating all possible distributive laws between two monad containers, which may help in developing no-go theorems for distributive laws between a larger class of monads.
280dia-0001dia-0001.xmlResearch diary20241113
I was previously using Obsidian for my research diary, but I found it a little heavyweight for what I was using it for: weekly (or fortnightly) notes on what I've been thinking about.
Being able to "transclude" trees into other ones is one of the reasons I'm using Forester for this. Writing definitions once and then including them as many times as needed seems far better than having to jump between files.
Most recent entry 281abt-0001abt-0001.xmlAbout this website20241113
This website uses the Forester tool developed by Jon Sterling. See Jon's website for tutorials/information about the tool.
It is a fantastic way to organise notes and I've been enjoying it a lot! There is even a VSCode plugin.

Let S \triangleright P be a container. A mnd-container (or monad container) on S \triangleright P is given by the following data: \begin {align*} \iota &: S\\ \sigma &: \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to S) \to S\\ \text {pr} &: \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to S\}} P\ (\sigma \ s\ f) \to \sum _{p : P\ s} P\ (f\ p) \end {align*} For which the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a ) &= a\\ \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) &= a\\ \sigma \ (\sigma \ a\ f)\ (\lambda p . g\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\ (\text {pr}_2\ p)) &= \sigma \ a\ (\lambda p . \sigma \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_1\ p) &= \text {pr}_1\ p\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) \end {align*} We abbreviate \pi _1 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_1 and \pi _2 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_2. The last three laws hold up the "associativity" law for \sigma .

fr:p.fr:em: TODO: define monad container interpretation and statement that all monads on container extension functors arise as monad containers. Maybe I should reference Uustalu here? I need a separate reference tree for that anyway.
